Epithelial Cell.definition: Cells lining the surfaces of the lung, including airways and alveoli, responsible for barrier function, gas exchange, and mucociliary clearance.

Airway Epithelium.definition: The pseudostratified epithelium of the conducting airways, from the trachea to the terminal bronchioles.

Basal Cell.definition: The primary stem cell of the proximal airways, responsible for self-renewal and differentiation into other luminal cell types.

Suprabasal Cell.definition: A transient, intermediate cell state migrating from the basal layer and committed to differentiation.

Secretory-Primed Basal Cell.definition: A subpopulation of basal cells molecularly primed to assume secretory cell fates.

Secretory Cell.definition: Cells responsible for producing the protective airway mucus layer.

Club Cell.definition: The primary secretory cell of the smaller bronchioles, producing secretoglobins.

Goblet Cell.definition: The primary mucin-producing cell (MUC5AC+) of the larger airways.

Nasal Secretory Cell.definition: A secretory cell population in the nasal epithelium, molecularly distinct from tracheobronchial secretory cells.

Ciliated Cell.definition: Terminally differentiated cells responsible for mucociliary clearance via motile cilia.

Deuterosomal Cell.definition: A transient precursor state to a mature ciliated cell, characterized by massive centriole amplification.

Mature Ciliated Cell.definition: The functional, motile ciliated cell responsible for mucus transport.

Rare Airway Epithelial Cells.definition: A group of low-abundance cells with critical sensory and regulatory functions.

Ionocyte.definition: A rare cell type identified as the primary site of CFTR expression, regulating ion and fluid balance.

Tuft Cell.definition: A chemosensory cell that initiates type 2 immune responses in the airway.

Tuft-1 Cell.definition: A distinct molecular subtype of Tuft cell.

Tuft-2 Cell.definition: A distinct molecular subtype of Tuft cell.

Basal/Tuft Hybrid Cell.definition: A likely progenitor state with features of both Basal and Tuft cells.

Pulmonary Neuroendocrine Cell.definition: Sensory cells (PNEC) that release neuropeptides in response to airway stimuli, often clustered in Neuroepithelial Bodies (NEBs).

Hillock Cell.definition: A novel epithelial population associated with dividing cells in the airways.

Submucosal Gland Epithelium.definition: Epithelial cells of the glands located deep within the walls of the trachea and large bronchi.

SMG Mucous Cell.definition: The primary MUC5B-producing mucin cell of the submucosal glands.

SMG Serous Cell.definition: A submucosal gland cell that secretes antimicrobial proteins, including lysozyme and lactoferrin.

SMG Duct Cell.definition: Epithelial cell forming the duct that transports gland secretions to the airway surface.

SMG Myoepithelial Cell.definition: A basal, contractile cell surrounding the submucosal gland acini, responsible for expelling secretions.

Alveolar Epithelium.definition: The epithelial lining of the distal gas-exchange region (the alveoli).

Alveolar Type 1 Cell.definition: The extremely thin, large squamous cell (AT1) that covers ~95% of the alveolar surface and is the primary site of gas exchange.

Alveolar Type 2 Cell.definition: The cuboidal cell (AT2) responsible for producing pulmonary surfactant and serving as the primary progenitor of the alveolus.

Alveolar Epithelial Progenitor.definition: A functionally distinct subset of AT2 cells (AEP), often Wnt-responsive, that serves as the principal homeostatic stem cell.

Mature AT2 Cell.definition: The terminally differentiated AT2 cell, primarily responsible for surfactant production.

Transitional Alveolar Epithelial Cell.definition: Transient cell states representing the differentiation trajectory from AT2 to AT1 cells, especially after injury.

KRT8+ Transitional Epithelial Cell.definition: A consensus damage-associated transient progenitor state (DATP or PATS) implicated in regeneration and fibrosis.

Immune Cell.definition: Cells of the immune system residing in or trafficking through the lung.

Myeloid Cell.definition: Innate immune cells, including macrophages, dendritic cells, and monocytes.

Macrophage.definition: The most abundant immune cell in the lung, responsible for phagocytosis and immune regulation.

Alveolar Macrophage.definition: Resident macrophages of the alveolar airspace (lumen).

IGF1+ Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages.

CCL18+ Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages.

CXCL5+ Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages.

Cholesterol-biosynthesis Alveolar Macrop.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages defined by cholesterol metabolism genes.

Chemokine-defined Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages defined by chemokine expression.

Metallothionein-defined Alveolar Macroph.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages defined by metallothionein expression.

Interferon-response Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages in an interferon-activated state.

Small-cluster Alveolar Macrophage.definition: A distinct functional subcluster of alveolar macrophages.

Interstitial Macrophage.definition: Resident macrophages that reside within the lung tissue (interstitium).

Dendritic Cell.definition: Professional antigen-presenting cells (APCs) responsible for initiating adaptive immune responses.

Conventional DC 1.definition: A subtype of conventional dendritic cells (cDC1) specialized in cross-presentation.

Conventional DC 2.definition: A subtype of conventional dendritic cells (cDC2) specialized in polarizing CD4+ T cells.

Plasmacytoid DC.definition: A dendritic cell subtype (pDC) specialized in producing large amounts of type I interferon.

LAMP3+ DC.definition: A mature, migratory state of conventional DCs primed to travel to lymph nodes.

Monocyte.definition: Circulating immune cells recruited from the blood that differentiate into macrophages or DCs.

Classical Monocyte.definition: A monocyte subtype (CD14+) typically involved in inflammatory responses.

Non-classical Monocyte.definition: A monocyte subtype (CD16+) involved in patrolling the endothelium.

Intermediate Monocyte.definition: A transitional monocyte state between classical and non-classical subtypes.

Granulocyte.definition: Innate immune cells characterized by cytoplasmic granules, including neutrophils, mast cells, eosinophils, and basophils.

Mast Cell.definition: A granulocyte involved in allergy and inflammatory responses.

Neutrophil.definition: A highly abundant, phagocytic granulocyte that is a first responder to infection.

Eosinophil.definition: A granulocyte primarily involved in responding to parasitic infections and allergic reactions.

Basophil.definition: A rare granulocyte involved in allergic responses.

Lymphoid Cell.definition: Adaptive and innate immune cells, including T cells, B cells, and ILCs.

T Cell.definition: A type of lymphocyte that plays a central role in cell-mediated immunity.

CD4+ T Cell.definition: Conventional T-helper cells that coordinate immune responses.

CD8+ T Cell.definition: Cytotoxic T cells that kill infected or malignant cells.

Regulatory T Cell.definition: A suppressive T cell (Treg) crucial for maintaining immune homeostasis and tolerance.

Mucosal-Associated Invariant T Cell.definition: An unconventional T cell (MAIT) abundant at mucosal sites like the lung.

Tissue-Resident Memory T Cell.definition: A non-circulating memory T cell (TRM) that provides long-term local immunity.

AREG+ CD4+ TRM.definition: A functional subtype of CD4+ TRM involved in tissue repair.

IFNG+ CD4+ TRM.definition: A functional subtype of CD4+ TRM with a pro-inflammatory, interferon-producing phenotype.

B Cell Lineage.definition: Cells mediating humoral (antibody) immunity, including B cells and their terminally differentiated state, Plasma cells.

B Cell.definition: Lymphocytes that produce antibodies and present antigens.

Naive B Cell.definition: A B cell that has not yet been activated by an antigen.

Memory B Cell.definition: A long-lived, antigen-experienced B cell capable of a rapid response upon re-infection.

Regulatory B Cell.definition: A B cell subset (Breg) with immune-suppressive functions.

Plasma Cell.definition: Terminally differentiated B cells that are highly specialized for secreting antibodies.

Innate Lymphoid Cell.definition: Innate lymphocytes (ILCs) that mirror the functions of T-helper cells but lack antigen-specific receptors.

ILC1.definition: An innate lymphoid cell that produces IFNG, mirroring Th1 cells.

ILC2.definition: An innate lymphoid cell that produces Type 2 cytokines (IL-5, IL-13), mirroring Th2 cells.

CRTH2+ ILC2.definition: Canonical ILC2 population, typically expressing CRTH2.

CRTH2- ILC2.definition: A novel ILC2 subpopulation identified in the lung.

ILC3.definition: An innate lymphoid cell that produces IL-17/IL-22, mirroring Th17 cells.

NCR+ ILC3.definition: A subtype of ILC3 expressing natural cytotoxicity receptors (NCR).

NCR- ILC3.definition: A subtype of ILC3 lacking natural cytotoxicity receptors (NCR).

Natural Killer Cell.definition: Cytotoxic innate lymphocytes (NK cells) that target virally infected and cancerous cells.

CD56bright NK Cell.definition: A tissue-resident NK cell population, typically less cytotoxic but high in cytokine production.

CD56dim NK Cell.definition: The dominant cytotoxic NK cell in peripheral blood, also found infiltrating the lung.

Mesenchymal Cell.definition: Structural (stromal) cells of the lung, providing the connective tissue framework and niche signaling.

Fibroblast.definition: Cells responsible for synthesizing and maintaining the extracellular matrix (ECM).

Alveolar Fibroblast.definition: Also known as Lipofibroblast. A fibroblast in the alveolar interstitium containing lipid droplets, critical for supporting AT2 stem cells.

Adventitial Fibroblast.definition: Fibroblasts located in the adventitia, the connective tissue cuff surrounding airways and blood vessels.

Matrix Fibroblast.definition: The primary collagen-producing fibroblast responsible for the bulk of the lung's ECM.

Myofibroblast.definition: A contractile, high-ECM-producing cell rare in healthy lungs but common in fibrosis.

Mural Cell.definition: Contractile cells associated with the walls of airways and the vasculature.

Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Contractile cells that regulate the diameter of airways and blood vessels.

Airway Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Smooth muscle cell surrounding the bronchi and bronchioles, controlling airway caliber.

Vascular Smooth Muscle Cell.definition: Smooth muscle cell surrounding arteries and veins, controlling vascular tone.

Pericyte.definition: Mural cells embedded in the basement membrane of capillaries and microvessels.

Type 1 Pericyte.definition: A quiescent pericyte population associated with capillaries.

Mesothelial Cell.definition: Specialized cells of mesenchymal origin that form the visceral pleura, the serous membrane lining the outside of the lung.

Chondrocyte.definition: Cells responsible for maintaining the cartilaginous rings of the trachea and large bronchi.

Endothelial Cell.definition: Cells that form the lining of all blood and lymphatic vessels.

Vascular Endothelial Cell.definition: Cells lining the blood vessels (arteries, veins, and capillaries).

Arterial Endothelial Cell.definition: Endothelial cells lining the pulmonary arteries.

Venous Endothelial Cell.definition: Endothelial cells lining the pulmonary veins, distinct from systemic veins.

Pulmonary Venous Endothelial Cell.definition: Venous endothelial cells located in the lung parenchyma, part of the main pulmonary circulation.

Systemic Venous Endothelial Cell.definition: Venous endothelial cells located in the airway walls, part of the systemic (bronchial) circulation.

Capillary Endothelial Cell.definition: The critical interface for gas exchange, resolved into two distinct types.

Aerocyte.definition: The definitive gas-exchange endothelial cell (aCap), forming the extremely thin air-blood barrier with AT1 cells.

General Capillary Cell.definition: A thicker capillary cell (gCap) not specialized for gas exchange; functions as a progenitor and has immune roles.

Lymphatic Endothelial Cell.definition: Cells lining the lymphatic drainage vessels, crucial for fluid homeostasis and immune cell trafficking.

Neuronal Cell.definition: Cells of the nervous system that are resident in or innervate the lung.

Pulmonary Sensory Neuron.definition: Viscerosensory neurons (nodose-derived) that monitor the internal state of the lung.

Somatosensory Neuron.definition: Neurons (jugular-derived) involved in somatosensory perception, such as nociception (cough).

Hematopoietic-derived Resident Cell.definition: Non-immune cells of hematopoietic origin that take up long-term residence in the lung.

Megakaryocyte.definition: A unique, immune-active population of lung-resident megakaryocytes (MkL) capable of activating T cells.

Erythroid Cell.definition: Cells of the red blood cell lineage, often captured in lung tissue digests.
